title: Oppo Pad 3 Relaunched as “OnePlus Pad” for Chinese Markets
description: OnePlus breathes new life into the Oppo Pad 3. The post Oppo Pad 3 Relaunched as “OnePlus Pad” for Chinese Markets appeared first on Phandroid.
author: Mike Viray
excerpt: OnePlus breathes new life into the Oppo Pad 3.
text: It’s been a while since the Oppo Pad 3 was launched, although Oppo’s sister company OnePlus saw it fit to rebrand the midrange tablet as the “OnePlus Pad” for Chinese markets, which comes with pretty much a lot of the same hardware and software features found on the Oppo Pad 3. READ: Meet Oppo’s Newest Midrange Tablet Aside from a new green color model, the China-exclusive OnePlus Pad packs the same design and specs as seen on its Oppo counterpart – this includes the Dimensity 8350 chipset inside, the same 11.61-inch IPS screen with a 2000 x 2,800 pixel aspect ratio, a 9,520 mAh battery with 67W charging support, and options for either 8GB or 12GB RAM variants. As with most tablets on the market, you get two cameras – an 8MP shooter for selfies and video calls, and another 8MP lens on the rear of the tablet. It stays pretty affordable as well, going for as much as $275 (when converted). Given that it’s a China-exclusive device however, the odds of seeing it in other markets might be unlikely. Source: GSMArena
html:
It’s been a while since the Oppo Pad 3 was launched, although Oppo’s sister company OnePlus saw it fit to rebrand the midrange tablet as the “OnePlus Pad” for Chinese markets, which comes with pretty much a lot of the same hardware and software features found on the Oppo Pad 3.

READ: Meet Oppo’s Newest Midrange Tablet

Aside from a new green color model, the China-exclusive OnePlus Pad packs the same design and specs as seen on its Oppo counterpart – this includes the Dimensity 8350 chipset inside, the same 11.61-inch IPS screen with a 2000 x 2,800 pixel aspect ratio, a 9,520 mAh battery with 67W charging support, and options for either 8GB or 12GB RAM variants.

As with most tablets on the market, you get two cameras – an 8MP shooter for selfies and video calls, and another 8MP lens on the rear of the tablet. It stays pretty affordable as well, going for as much as $275 (when converted). Given that it’s a China-exclusive device however, the odds of seeing it in other markets might be unlikely.

Source: GSMArena
